title: EU referendum: Cameron says IMF report shows Brexit poses 'major risks for UK economy' - Politics live | Politics | The Guardian
summary: farage says imf has been 'hijacked by architects of failing eu project '
cameron says imf report shows brexit poses 'major risks for the uk economy '
crabb says employment gap between disabled and non-disabled 'simply unacceptable '
mps hold emergency debate on the steel industry .
eu referendum uncertainty could be pushing up inflation , says iod .
zac goldsmith publishes his london mayoral manifesto .
ministers have intensified efforts to get tory supporters on public bodies , appointments chief says .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: david cameron has said that today 's report from the imf shows that leaving the eu would pose major risks for the uk economy '' .
( see 2.45pm . )
and david miliband , the labour former foreign secretary , has said the report amounts to a absolutely devastating '' judgment on brexit .
miliband said : this is a stark warning that should ring loudly in the ears of families and businesses across the country .
there is a storm on our horizon .
we can hear the thunder if we are willing to listen .
but it is in our power to protect ourselves .
but politicians and organisations opposed to eu membership have argued that the imf 's views can be discounted because it has a record of getting its forecasts and its judgments wrong .
( see 3.37pm and 3.43pm . )
matthew elliott , chief executive of vote leave , said : the imf has talked down the british economy in the past and now it is doing it again at the request of our own chancellor .
it was wrong then and it is wrong now .
the irony is that if we vote remain our voice at the imf will be silenced as the eu wants to take our seat at the top table in return for the £ 350m we hand to brussels every week .

the biggest risk to the uk 's economy and security is remaining in an unreformed eu which is institutionally incapable of dealing with the challenges it faces , such as the euro and migration crises .
lynne owens , director general of the national crime agency , has said efforts to fight serious crime could be at risk if britain leaves eu .
as the press association reports , owens said said it was possible that other nations could refuse to hand over information or criminals following a brexit vote .
she indicated that important law enforcement arrangements currently in place would have to be re-cast , potentially creating a period of gap '' .
owens said : my responsibility is to lead the fight to cut serious and organised crime in this country and anything that makes that easier i would support .

if we were to leave europe i would hope there could be processes put in place to make that easier but you can see there could be a situation where we have a period of gap and that could create a risk .
the electoral reform society has published a report arguing that citizens are ready , willing and able to take part in participatory and deliberative forms of democracy '' .

democracy matters describes the result of a pilot involving two citizens assemblies ( people chosen at random to get involved in local decision making ) and it says there is a genuine appetite for stronger devolution , with more public involement '' .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .

documents.title: farage says imf has been 'hijacked by architects of failing eu project '
text: and here is nigel farage , the ukip leader , on the imf report .
the imf has been hijacked by the architects of the failing eu project , so of course they want the uk to remain .

this is all about the big banks and the establishment protecting their interests within a cosy eu cartel that looks after multi-national corporations and dismisses the democratic wishes of the average man , woman or small and medium sized business .
the imf was wrong when it supported the euro , wrong when it failed to predict the global recession and is wrong now it is trying to scare the british people .
nigel farage wigglesworth/ap
groups campaigning against eu membership have dismissed the warnings from the imf about brexit .
this is from peter bone , a conservative mp and a spokesman for grassroots out ( go ) .
the imf supported the failed euro - and now supports the uk remaining in the eu at the request of the british government .

we can not trust scaremongering from these establishment organisations when they have been wrong on the euro , failed to predict the credit crisis and have been consistently wrong in predicting uk economic performance .

the real risk to the uk economy is remaining in a failing eu club that will tax our financial services , depress wages via mass migration and continue to impose burdensome red tape on our small and medium sized businesses .
peter bone pruchnie/getty images and this is from brian monteith , a spokesman for leave.eu .

with so many corporate elites predicting armageddon after brexit , it 's hard to believe that the many successful economies outside the eu are able to function at all without expensive supra-national bureaucracies telling them what to do .
olivier blanchard , the imf 's chief economist until the end of 2015 , had to admit that they had seriously underestimated the uk economy just a couple of years ago .
they are doing the same thing now .
indeed , when was the last time the imf actually got a forecast right ?
they have an appalling record for getting things wrong , with severe repercussions for countries like greece .
this latest fantasy , based on false assumptions about imaginary trade wars , pre-empted by international agreements as well as the eu 's own treaties , is just the latest .

documents.title: crabb says employment gap between disabled and non-disabled 'simply unacceptable '
text: stephen crabb has given his first major speech in his new role as work and pensions secretary .
he said that the employment gap between the disabled and the non-disabled was simply unacceptable '' and that getting more disabled people into work would be one of his priorities .
some 300,000 extra disabled people have moved into work over the past two years , crabb said .
but , despite this , the employment rate for non-disabled people is 80 % , compared with less than 50 % for the disabled , he said .
in the context of a very strong labour market and the millions of people that have moved into work over the last few years , that gap is simply unacceptable .
this employment gap is n't because of a lack of aspiration on the part of sick and disabled people .
we know the majority want to work or stay in work .
some attitudes held by society have stopped disabled people from moving into work for many decades .
i want to challenge health and care professionals , employers and wider society to break down those barriers .
stephen crabb court/getty images

documents.title: cameron says imf report shows brexit poses 'major risks for the uk economy '
text: david cameron has been tweeting about the imf 's warning about the dangers of brexit .
david cameron ( @ david cameron ) the imf is right - leaving the eu would pose major risks for the uk economy .
we are stronger , safer and better off in the european union .
the imf report came out at 2pm .
our story on it is here .
imf says britain leaving the eu is a significant risk read more

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: sajid javid , the business secretary , has indicated that the government would consider taking on some of the debt associated with the port talbot steelworks .

speaking in an emergency debate on steel , he made the comment when asked to clarify what he meant when he told mps yesterday that the government was open to co-investing '' on commercial terms with a firm buying tata 's uk steel business .
asked what this meant , javid replied : that was in relation to tata strip and their decision to sell their business .

and what i set out there is really to show , when the government says it will look at all options to help frame a long-term viable business with a commercial operator , then that would be such an option .
the key point is that any co-investment would have to be on commercial terms .
investment can take a variety of forms ; for example , it could be debt .
it 's a demonstration of all the options the government is looking at .
but number 10 ruled out nationalisation .
that was not the right answer '' , the prime minister 's spokewoman said .
the imf has said a british vote to leave the eu risks causing severe economic and political damage to europe that will spill over into an already febrile world economy .

william hague , the conservative former foreign secretary , has said voters should beware of judging politicians by their tax returns , because some of britain 's greatest leaders - including winston churchill - had chaotic '' personal finances .
tax avoidance by multinational corporations will be forced into the open under proposals to be unveiled by european regulators on tuesday following the panama papers revelations .
zac goldsmith , the tory mayoral candidate for london , cast himself as on the side of the heroes '' while his labour rival 's career involved coaching people how to sue our police '' .

as randeep ramesh reports , at the launch of goldsmith'smanifesto , which focused on green issues , housing and transport , the tory mp opened a new front over law and order claiming his opponent would be soft on crime because he provided cover for extremists '' .

in his speech , goldsmith said labour 's sadiq khan was a politician who had given platforms , oxygen and even cover - over and over and over again - to those who seek to do our police and capital harm '' .
labour has called on the government to reject a proposed overhaul of the appointments process for senior public jobs , amid fears that it could lead to a rise in cronyism .
the conservative mp david davis said the british government is treating the entire nation as suspects '' by ignoring safeguards on retaining and accessing personal communications data .

speaking before the opening of a test case at the european court of justice ( ecj ) , the former home affairs spokesman called for improved protections to prevent state abuses through bulk interception of private emails and online exchanges .
david miliband , the former foreign secretary , has said antisemitism is repulsive '' and must be exposed and defeated , amid growing controversy over racism against jews within the labour party .
a data watchdog is examining claims the personal details of supporters of vote leave , the group campaigning to leave the eu , could be accessed on its website .

as the press association reports , the lib dem leader tim farron lodged a complaint with the information commissioner 's office ( ico ) about what he called a serious breach '' of protection rules that left personal details plastered all over the internet '' .

names , addresses , phone numbers and personal messages of those signing up to the vote leave website were said to have been relatively easily accessible by others despite claims they would be kept in secure environments '' .
the loophole has apparently since been closed , the lib dems said .
the ons has said that that inflation jumped to 0.5 % in the year to march after a rise in the cost of air fares over easter and more expensive spring and summer clothing ranges hitting stores .
sajid javid has now finished his speech .
angela eagle was not impressed .
angela eagle ( @ angelaeagle ) a very self congratulatory performance from business secretary & no answers to my questions today .
# saveoursteel i will post a summary soon .
javid says co-investment in port talbot could involve the government taking on some debt .
rowena mason ( @ rowenamason ) javid asked to clarify what govt `` co-investment '' in steel means .
he says wd have to be on commercial terms , could be debt rather than equity
richard fuller , a conservative , asks javid what he meant when he talked about co-investment '' yesterday .
javid says he was trying to make the point that the government was open to all options for the future of the tata steelworks at port talbot .
that could involve help on commercial terms in a variety of forms , he says .
labour 's stephen doughty asks javid if he thinks the rebar tariff is high enough .
javid says the 99 % fall in chinese imports suggests that tariff is effective .
labour 's adrian bailey says steel producers are worried that giving china market economy status will make it harder for the eu to take it to court over dumping .
javid says it will be up to the eu collectively to decide whether to give it market economy status .
and , even if a country gets it , the eu can still impose tariffs , he says .
sir edward leigh , a conservative , says it should be up to the uk to decide whether it takes action over dumping , not the eu .
javid says the lesser duty rule benefits british consumers .
in the shoe market , it has been worth £ 130m to them , he says .
javid says , where the evidence shows that tariffs can make a difference without affecting uk consumers , he will back them .
he says in july last year the government backed a 16 % tariff on wire rod .
imports from china dropped by 90 % .
in november it backed a 28 % tariff on seamless pipes .
that led to an 80 % fall in chinese imports .
in january it backed an 11 % tariff on rebar .
chinese imports fell by 99 % , javid says .
and in february the government backed a 15 % tariff on cold-rolled flat products .
chinese imports fell to almost zero , he says .
he says these moves have helped british steelworkers .
javid says the government has taken advantage of new eu rules making it easier for the public sector to order locally-made steel .
labour 's stephen doughty asks why mps should accept this given that , when he asked the mod where their steel came from , it was unable to tell him .
javid says he thinks the mod will be making a further announcement on this topic in the coming days .
javid says that the government had taken steps to help high-energy producers like steel factories with their energy costs , but that he would consider going further .
blenkinsop is not happy with the reply he received from javid .
tom blenkinsop ( @ tomblenkinsop ) repetition of £ 80m by javid , when he admitted prior the fig is more like £ 50m , @ the despatch box , is just inflaming the debate # saveoursteel
sajid javid , the business secretary , is speaking now .
he says the steel industry is in crisis around the world because of massive over-supply .
this amounts to a human tragedy , he says .
where job losses have happened in britain , the government has done everything possible to help the communities affected .
labour 's david anderson intervenes .
he says he was one of the people affected when the tories close coal mines 30 years ago .
and then the government did nothing to help the communities affected , he says .
javid says he is sure anderson accepts government will help when it can .
labour 's tom blenkinsop says the government did not do all it promised to do to help redcar when the ssi plant closed there .
javid says only a quarter of the ssi workers from redcar are currently on the dole .
sajid javid
eagle says there were reports the government was going to exclude plant and machinery from business rates .
george osborne even apparently costed this out , she says .
but she says osborne dropped this in favour of his economically illiterate and increasingly unachievable surplus rule '' , she says .
angela eagle
eagle says the goverment should abandon its opposition to the abolition of the lesser duty rule that limits the eu 's ability to impose tariffs on china .
it should block unfair chinese imports , she says .
and she criticises the government for scrapping a rule that existed when labour was in office saying the mod should favour british steel when awarded procurement contracts .
eagle says she wants sajid javid to confirm that he will avoid a firesale '' of tata 's assets .
tata should only consider an offer from a buyer willing to maintain both upstream and downstream assets , she says .
she says tata say they want to leave the uk in four months .
but a sale could take longer , she says .
in the commons labour 's clive betts says the government has still not said what it might do on energy prices or business rates to help the steel industry .
eagle says she hopes the government will give details during the debate .
at the number 10 lobby briefing today the prime minister 's spokeswoman said that , whatever sajid javid said about co-investing '' , the government would not be nationalising tata 's steel plants .
this is from itv 's libby weiner .
libby wiener ( @ libbywieneritv ) nationalisation is 'not the right answer ' says pm 's spokeswoman , when asked about 'co-investment ' # steelcrisis

the labour mp david anderson intervenes to criticise the government for recalling parliament to pay tribute to margaret thatcher after she died , but refusing to recall parliament to debate the steel crisis .
eagle says she thinks parliament should have been recalled , but we are where we are '' .
angela eagle , the shadow business secretary , is opening the debate .
jeremy corbyn is on the labour frontbench alongside her .
she says she hopes that sajid javid will explain what he meant yesterday when he talked about the government co-investing '' with a buyer .
she says the government has been behind , rather than ahead of events .
its response has been a mixture of indifference and incompetence .

labour bis team ( @ labourbis ) the situation facing the steel industry can not be categorised as anything other than an emergency , says labour 's @ twitterid labour bis team ( @ labourbis ) government should spare ideological blushes and get on with saving the steel industry says @ twitterid effective action not just warm words labour bis team ( @ labourbis ) steel is a foundation industry - our automotive , aerospace and defence industries all rely on steel , says @ twitterid labour bis team ( @ labourbis ) much has been said about the cost of supporting our steel industry - but what about the costs of letting it be destroyed ?
asks @ twitterid labour bis team ( @ labourbis ) the end of steelmaking in the uk would have an economic cost and also an intolerable social cost , says @ twitterid
yesterday sajid javid , the business secretary , made a statement on steel to mps .
the guardian 's story about it is here .

uk ready to part-nationalise tata steel , says sajid javid read more in the statement javid said that the government was considering the possibility of co-investing '' on commercial terms with a buyer of tata 's uk business .
he refused to elaborate on what that might mean .
on the daily politics a few minutes ago stephen kinnock , the labour mp for aberavon , said that javid needed to clarify what he meant in the debate .

but esther mcvey , the former conservative mp and minister who was also on the programme , said that javid had to be vague when talking about what help the government might be able to offer a buyer because , if he were more specific , he might fall foul of eu state aid rules .

documents.title: mps hold emergency debate on the steel industry
text: mps are about to start an emergency debate on the steel industry .
in advance angela eagle , who requested the emergency debate , issued this statement .
today 's emergency debate on the steel industry is a reflection both of the importance of the industry , and the perfect storm it faces .
steel is a foundation industry which is absolutely essential for manufacturing and for our wider economy .
the tory business secretary ignored our warnings of the growing challenges facing steel for months .
and when the crisis came to a head , he was missing in action .
the debate today gives sajid javid the chance to come to the house with a comprehensive plan to secure the future of our vital steel industry .

we must see an integrated sale to ensure britain retains the ability to both make and process steel , to level the playing field by addressing the illegal dumping of chinese steel , and the development of a modern industrial strategy to support steel and manufacturing .

documents.title: eu referendum uncertainty could be pushing up inflation , says iod
text: here is some comment on today 's inflation figures .
michael martin , an economist at the institute for directors , says uncertainty surrounding the eu referendum could be pushing up inflation .
the slight rise in inflation is likely connected to depreciation of the pound as uncertainty surrounding the eu referendum increases and international investors begin to sell off sterling .
this is not a one-month phenomenon - core inflation , which strips out volatile factors like energy and food , increased to 1.5 % in march , after averaging 1.1 % over the last 8 months .
frances o'grady , the tuc general secretary , says the economy is still not at full strength '' .
despite a small rise , the overall is still of very low inflation .
it indicates that the economy is still not at full strength , with too much underemployment and too little wage growth .
with the global economy slowing down , the government can not just sit by .
we need investment in skills , infrastructure and public services to promote growth for the long term .
adam corlett , an economic analyst at the resolution foundation , says the inflation increase will dampen real wage growth .
while inflation remains close to historic lows , today 's larger than expected increase is set to dampen real wage growth .
our projection show that earnings growth may actually have slowed in recent months , emphasizing the need to get our pay recovery back on track .

documents.title: zac goldsmith publishes his london mayoral manifesto
text: zac goldsmith , the conservative candidate for london mayor , launched his manifesto this morning .
as the evening standard reports , he is claiming his policies would secure 500,000 new jobs '' for londoners .

he has arrived at that figure by arguing that his plan to build 50,000 homes a year would create 195,000 new jobs ; that his support for key infrastructure projects would create 286,000 jobs ; and that his plans for tech hubs and extending broadband would create more than 20,000 jobs .
interestingly , the 500,000 new jobs '' commitment does not appear in that form in the manifesto .
it looks as if it has been cobbled together for the news release .
the weakness with the claim is that sadiq khan , goldsmith 's labour rival , would also press ahead with more housing and new infrastructure .
but the tories do say employment in london rose by 438,000 in boris johnson 's second term as london mayor .
zac goldsmith ( left ) and boris johnson at the launch of goldsmith 's manifesto this morning .
rousseau/pa
two pollsters have published articles today arguing that the panama papers revelations about david cameron will have less impact on voting intention than people expect .
this is from an article by marcus roberts , the former fabian society deputy general secretary who is now international projects director at yougov , for the times 's red box morning email .
it may be useful to offer as a corrective a brief reminder on what this is all likely to actually mean to voters grappling with may 's elections and with remain v leave .
the short answer is : nowhere near as much as we might think .
why ?
well , take the prime minister 's tax affairs as an example .
what has this story revealed , and how might voters react ?
to the first question , the story reminds voters that the prime minister is a wealthy man .

but as the conservative arch strategist lynton crosby is fond of reminding people : after so many years of hearing it from the left , the voters may just about have worked out that right wing leaders have a bit of money . ''
so how might voters react to this ?
probably in much the same way as they would react to any story that confirms a pre-existing notion of a politician : namely , to reinforce it .
and this is from a blog by lord ashcroft , the pollster and former conservative deputy chairman .
the cameron tax story , then , boils down to three essential elements .
first , the camerons are rich .
( to anyone who did not know this already - a peruvian goatherd , perhaps , or a hermit - the last week 's news will have come as quite a revelation . )
second , they may have taken some steps to avoid paying any more tax than they had to .
third , nothing they did was against the law .
for some people , the question of legality is beside the point .
they will see the episode as further proof that the system works for the wealthy , who take care to arrange things to their advantage while claiming that we are all in it together .
legal obligations are one thing , they argue , but moral responsibilities are another .
this is a widespread view , even among people who have pensions and isas and enjoy duty-free shopping .
but how many of them now have a different opinion of david cameron from the one they had before mossack fonseca received all their unexpected publicity ?
for ( i suspect ) rather more people , stories like this are a sideshow .

as i noted in the unexpected mandate , my review of the 2015 election drawing on my research throughout the last parliament , cameron 's wealth has only really counted against him with those already least inclined to vote tory .
lord ashcroft thomond for the guardian

in his first speech to the labour party conference as party leader jeremy corbyn quoted a saying from the nigerian author ben okri : the most authentic thing about us is our capacity to create , to overcome , to endure , to transform , to love . ''
now the southbank centre has announced that the two men will appear together on stage in july to discuss poetry and politics .
tickets are on sale generally from tomorrow , although southbank centre members can book them from today .
the guardian has today launched a big the web we want '' project looking at the issue of online abuse .
as part of that we 're asking readers what we can to to improve online comments here .
the comments on this blog are a big part of what interesting to readers , but there is always room for improvement and , if you 've got suggestions , we would like to hear them .
there is a form here where you can comment .
how can we improve the guardian comments ?
share your views read more and here 's an article from mary hamilton , our executive editor for audience , explaining in more detail some of the problems and the issues that we are looking at .
the guardian wants to engage with readers , but how we do it needs to evolve read more
and while we 're still on about william hague , it is worth flagging up his column in today 's telegraph .
it covers the transparency issue and in it hague makes the same arguments he was making on the today programme .
he concludes with some lavish praise for david cameron .
having spent 10 years working nearly every day with this prime minister , there are many things i can say about him - but for now i highlight just one example .
when a british citizen is kidnapped overseas and held hostage , the machinery of government swings into action to determine whether and how to rescue them .

and whenever that happened in my time as foreign secretary i watched mr cameron spend many hours on each such case to an extent that surprised officials , as he looked at every option , quizzed the intelligence and military chiefs , and assessed every scrap of information on a matter that could mean life or death .
if you 're ever in that terrible situation you will not care if the prime minister received a gift of money from his mother .
you will only want to know that you have a prime minister who gives his patience , concentration and balance of judgment to the fate of one individual .
you 've got one .
that should always matter more than personal background or wealth .
openness from leaders needs a mature understanding of the qualities we need in them .

william hague 's comments about the perils of getting politicians to be more transparent about their tax affairs ( see 9.07am ) were rather mild compared to what some mps were telling the financial times .
here 's an extract from their story ( paywall ) .

mps have responded angrily to the possibility of being forced to publish their tax returns , describing the idea as completely ridiculous '' , knee jerk '' and reminiscent of the stasi or the kgb '' we are at the start of another expenses scandal , '' said the labour politician , referring to the events of 2009 when mps ' expenses claims were made public .
if they make every mp publish their tax receipts there will be some horrors in there ... and if it comes out just before the eu referendum then the consequences would be very serious . ''
other mps argue that forcing politicians to make this information public could put people off running for parliament .
if you 're going to make [ politics ] a minority sport for pygmies , then you have had it , '' said one long-serving conservative mp .
in norway everyone 's tax return is available online .
in the us legislators must provide an annual financial statement and many recent presidents and presidential candidates have voluntarily published their tax returns .
asked about such cases , the conservative mp said : that is not britain . ''

documents.title: ministers have intensified efforts to get tory supporters on public bodies , appointments chief says
text: sir david normington , the outgoing commissioner for public appointments , has told the financial times ( subscription ) that ministers have intensified efforts to ensure tory supporters get appointed to public bodies since the general election .
here 's an extract from sarah neville 's story .

sir david normington said the prime minister , or other members of the government , intervened about once a month to question why supporters such as donors , ex-mps or former office holders had not been shortlisted or recommended for key posts sir david recalled one occasion when none of the five applicants deemed suitable by ministers for an important public job had been put through for interview , since others were better qualified .
four of the five had substantial connections to the conservative party and there was , needless to say , a very unhappy secretary of state as a result and quite an argument about it , '' he said .
such interventions , while still representing a small minority of overall appointments , had noticeably increased in the past two years , beginning in the run-up to the 2015 general election .

one reason for this , he suggested , was the departure from government of the liberal democrats , which had led to fewer checks and balances , but also a feeling that if you want to get things done you need to have people who are your sympathisers working in some of the key roles '' , he said .

sir david normington commenting on the story , tom watson , labour 's deputy leader , said : it is vital we prevent important public roles like the chairman of the bbc trust or the heads of museums and galleries becoming politicised like they have been in the past .
sir david 's warning must be heeded and the government should rule out implementing the grimstone review in its current form .
these jobs are paid for by the taxpayer and they must be carried out by the people who are best qualified to do them .
we ca n't return to an age when they are doled out to political chronies as a reward for services rendered .
last month the government published a report from sir gerry grimstone recommending more flexibility '' in the rules goverrning public appointments .
normington told the ft he was worried these proposals would result in a return to the days of political and personal patronage '' .
tom watson ( front ) at a meeting of the shadow cabinet earlier this year .
rousseau/pa

documents.title: cpi inflation rises to 0.5 %
text: here 's the start of the press association story about today 's inflation figures .

consumer price inflation ( cpi ) is up to its highest level in 15 months - but it 's still only 0.5 % uk inflation lifted to its highest level for 15 months in march as the rising cost of clothes and air fares pushed up the cost of living .

the office for national statistics ( ons ) said consumer price index ( cpi ) inflation hit 0.5 % last month after the price of clothes rose by 1.7 % year on year , while passenger transport by air climbed 17.9 % over the same period .
the cost of flights also soared 22.9 % month on month , impacted by the early easter period .
but food prices fell 3 % year on year last month as grocers continue to slash prices amid the ongoing supermarket price war .

despite march 's cpi rise - up from 0.3 % in february - inflation still remains historically low , with the bank of england predicting it to stay far below the government 's target of 2 % for some time .
sharply lower oil prices have also put a dampener on inflation , leaving the central bank in no hurry to raise rates above 0.5 % , where they have remained for nearly seven years .
ons statistician phil gooding said : after an unprecedented period of cpi being close to zero , inflation has begun to rise again .
dearer clothing and higher air fares , influenced by the timing of easter , are behind the rise in cpi , which is still low by historic standards . ''
it comes after cpi remained at 0.3 % in february , the same as in january , as the falling cost of second-hand cars offset rising food prices .
the latest figures from the ons also show the retail prices index ( rpi ) measure of inflation rose to 1.6 % in march , up from 1.3 % in february .
here is the office for national statistics statistical bulletin .
and here is a chart from it showing cpi inflation figures for the last 10 years .
cpi inflation over the last 10 years

documents.title: david miliband urges corbyn to speak out in favour of eu membership
text: william hague was not the only former foreign secretary on the today programme this morning .
david miliband , the labour former foreign secretary , was interviewed too , because he is giving a major speech later on why britain should remain in the eu .
miliband has set out much of his argument in an article for today 's guardian .
here 's an extract .
if the world is increasingly divided between firefighters and arsonists then britain has , for centuries , been a firefighter .

this is no time for britain to join the ranks of arsonists , and there should be no doubt that brexit would be an act of arson on the international order far from limiting or diminishing us , the eu multiplies british power , ideas and values in very direct ways .
in defence policy , the eu allows the uk to mobilise international action , for example reducing somali pirate attacks .
in diplomatic policy , the eu was central to negotiating a resolution to the iranian nuclear programme .

our world-leading development and environmental clout are multiplied by our membership of the eu , which drives pioneering good practice on a global scale no nation in human peacetime history has voluntarily given up as much political power as we are being invited to throw away on 23 june .

the power to help set rules for the world 's largest single market , rather than accept the rules being set for us ; the power to help decide on the deployment of the largest humanitarian budget in the world ; the power to help shape the negotiation of global trade deals ; the power to help deploy the political resources of 28 countries .
in his interview miliband also said that he hoped jeremy corbyn would use a speech he is due to give later this week to make it very clear that he favoured britain staying remaining in the eu .
he told the programme : i have a slight sense that there 's a bit of a phony war at the moment , that the real battle over the european question has n't really started .
labour is unequivocally for britain to remain a major player in the european union .

if jeremy corbyn is able to say on thursday to those 50 % of labour voters who do n't yet know what labour 's position is 'we are unequivocally for ' , that can only be a good thing because labour voters - whether it be because of the social chapter or our economic gains , never mind our place in the world - have a huge amount to gain , and a huge amount to lose if we get this decision wrong .

corbyn and labour are in favour of staying in the eu , but corbyn has said little on this subject in public in recent months ( fuelling sus that his personal support for eu membership is decidedly lukewarm ) and a recent observer poll found 40 % of people do not know where he stands on the issue .
at the weekend four labour mps published an article saying corbyn should speak out more loudly in support of the eu .
david miliband segar/reuters
my colleague roy greenslade has written an assessment of how today 's papers are covering david cameron 's statement yesterday .
he says the coverage suggests that , for the moment , [ cameron ] may well have drawn a line under the affair . ''
rightwing press rallies to david cameron 's side over tax storm read more

david cameron may have got through the worst of the panama papers tax frenzy following his statement to the commons yesterday , but as a result of his new ruling about prime ministers and chancellors publishing their tax details ( the cameron doctrine ? )
british politics has probably made permanent shift in the direct of transparency .
but this is britain and the forces of conservatism do n't surrender easily .

on the today programme william hague this morning , the former foreign secretary and at one time one of the house of commons mega-earners because of his talents as an after-dinner speaker , issued a blunt message : let 's not take this too far .
hague supported cameron 's decision to release information about his tax returns .
but he said it was important for the public to remember that sometimes the best leaders may not have squeaky clean finances .

the consequence of greater transparency in tax , in medical records , whatever else it may be among leaders , is that there has to be a maturity in the public debate about those things and a recognition that the circumstances and habits of people who are effective leaders will vary greatly , and that those personal circumstances are not necessarily a good guide to how good they will be as a prime minister , a chancellor or anything else .
we 've had leaders in the history of our country who 've had chaotic personal finances , like william pitt the younger , but who were brilliant at handling the nation 's finances .
we 've had leaders who 've had tax returns , like churchill , that would have been more difficult to defend in public than prime minister david cameron 's tax returns .
but churchill was the greatest leader of modern times .
so we are going to have to bear those things in mind and not expect everybody to be perfect or everybody to be normal .
and he said it would be a mistake if mps introduced rules that kept business figures out of the commons .

if parliament consisted of people who had the simplest possible personal finances , perhaps all having come through the public sector , with no questions of business ownership or dividends or anything else , then you would have a very one dimensional parliament .
so there is a danger of that .
hague said the solution was to introduce transparency in careful stages '' .
let 's see how it works , he argued .
if there is any more on this , i will post it as it comes up .
here is the agenda for the day .
9.30am : inflation figures are released .
9.45am : zac goldsmith , the conservative candidate for london mayor , launches his manifesto .
11am : paul johnson , director of the institute for fiscal studies , gives evidence to the commons treasury committee about the budget .
12pm : carwyn jones , the welsh first minister , launches labour 's election campaign in wales .
12.20pm : stephen crabb , the new work and pensions secretary , gives a speech at the early intervention foundation around 12.40pm : mps begin an emergency debate on the steel industry .
2pm : david miliband , the former labour foreign secretary , gives a speech on the eu referendum .
3pm : sir malcolm rifkind , liam fox , alex salmond and gisela stuart give evidence to the commons foreign affairs committee about the eu referendum .

i will probably cover the start of the steel debate in detail and i will also be covering other breaking political news as it happens , as well as bringing you the best reaction , comment and analysis from the web .
i will post a summary at lunchtime ( probably ) and another in the afternoon .
if you want to follow me or contact me on twitter , i 'm on @ andrewsparrow .
i try to monitor the comments btl but normally i find it impossible to read them all .
if you have a direct question , do include andrew '' in it somewhere and i 'm more likely to find it .
i do try to answer direct questions , although sometimes i miss them or do n't have time .
alternatively you could post a question to me on twitter .

if you think there are any voices that i 'm leaving out , particularly political figures or organisations giving alternative views of the stories i 'm covering , do please flag them up below the line ( include andrew '' in the post ) .
i ca n't promise to include everything , but i do try to be open to as wide a range of perspectives as possible .
